title: If there was no matter, space or energy, would time still have meaning? - Quora

response.answer_text: I think those things go together. I don’t think you get time without space and “things.” I think things have relationships with other things, and we sentient humans have just sussed out that we can attach labels with numeric values to stuff such that we can do calculations with those numbers and make predictions about the future. I think it’s about “things.” Exactly what those things are, I don’t know for sure - they could be material, or they could be mind stuff, or some of both. But I don’t think that space and time, or spacetime if you prefer, are fundamental. I think we concoct that as we try to make sense out of our perceptions. Time comes easier, I think - there are causes and there are effects - cause precedes effect. With a large enough number of events going on, that defines a near-continuum. Space - that’s a little different. It means that causes can’t produce any old effect they please. They have to “prepare the way.” We’ve quantified that, and it winds up looking to us like “going to the right place to take the causal action.” I suspect it’s “mind stuff” that’s actually fundamental, and not “material stuff,” but that’s not really your question. Hope this helps some.

I’ve been wondering about this myself, but I’ll state the question slightly differently; since mass, energy and speed shape the relationship between time and space, would time and space have meaning in the absence of mass and energy? My thoughts go like this; everywhere we look in the universe there is a small amount of cosmic background radiation, so nowhere is there space in an absolutely zero state, and so even at these places time and space exist in a state close to what we know here. Near a black hole though space is almost infinitely compressed and time is dilated till it has nearly stopped. Perhaps at zero mass and energy state time is infinitely compressed while space is infinitely dilated? But beyond that conjecture, time and space will theoretically exist in a base state without matter and energy, but you can’t have time without space or space without time, and space will always have an odd number of dimensions. (https://www.researchgate.net/publication/1995675_Why_odd-space_and_odd-time_dimensions_in_even-dimesional_spaces)

No, as a matter of fact, without a conscious observer, time would have no meaning. Which is to say, even if there are billions of years between the last conscious observer dying on some planet, and the next conscious observer crawling out of some primordial ooze on some future planet, that transition would be instantaneous.

One of the key revolutions of special relativity and Lorentz transforms in general was the realization that time and space are not cleanly separable concepts. Time and space are part of the same thing. What one observer sees as two events at one spot at different times, another observer can see separated in space and more time. So without space, there is no time, and vice versa.

Without any matter, energy, or space, there would be nothing to perceive the passage of time, at least as we understand it. So no, it would have no meaning. It may still keep trucking along by itself for all we know, but it would have no effect.

This question is dealt with at some length in e.g. Roger Penrose’s ‘Cycles of Time’, and elsewhere in different ways or through different approaches (e.g. If You Thought Quantum Mechanics Was Weird, Wait Till You Hear About Entangled Time etc.) and the answer is a resounding no.
